text:
I'm trying to download files using `HTTP.download` but I can't get the authorization to work.

The `wget` instructions are:
```wget --http-user=<username> --http-password=<password> --load-cookies mycookies.txt --save-cookies mycookies.txt --keep-session-cookies --no-check-certificate --auth-no-challenge -r --reject "index.html*" -np -e robots=off ```
But this doesn't work:
```HTTP.download(url; user="username", password="password", cookies=true)```
Can I replicate those flags with HTTP?

The curl instructions are:
```curl -b ~/.urs_cookies -c ~/.urs_cookies -L -n -O <url>```

elements.text: I'm trying to download files using
HTTP.download

but I can't get the authorization to work.

The
wget
instructions are:

wget --http-user=<username> --http-password=<password> --load-cookies mycookies.txt --save-cookies mycookies.txt --keep-session-cookies --no-check-certificate --auth-no-challenge -r --reject "index.html*" -np -e robots=off
But this doesn't work:
HTTP.download(url; user="username", password="password", cookies=true)

Can I replicate those flags with HTTP?

The curl instructions are:
curl -b ~/.urs_cookies -c ~/.urs_cookies -L -n -O <url>

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
:bridge:
Seems `user` and `password` aren't keywords thats from something else, HTTP just silently ignores unknown keywords. Seems this needs an Authorization header manually constructed?

elements.text: Seems
user
and
password
aren't keywords thats from something else, HTTP just silently ignores unknown keywords. Seems this needs an Authorization header manually constructed?

text:
> Basic Authentication options
> Basic authentication is detected automatically from the provided url’s userinfo (in the form <scheme://user>:password@host) and adds the Authorization: Basic header
<https://juliaweb.github.io/HTTP.jl/stable/public_interface/#Public-Interface>

elements.text:
Basic Authentication options
Basic authentication is detected automatically from the provided url’s userinfo (in the form
:password@host) and adds the Authorization: Basic header

text: Oh right, thanks. It's at least failing with an error now :))

elements.text: Oh right, thanks. It's at least failing with an error now :))

text: The basic wget actually works with none of those parameters, just user and password. But `HTTP.download` still doesn't work using `scheme`. It throws and `IOerror` connection refused error.

elements.text: The basic wget actually works with none of those parameters, just user and password. But
HTTP.download
still doesn't work using
scheme
. It throws and
IOerror
connection refused error.

text: Oh no actually it's just returning the login page - I had a typo.

elements.text: Oh no actually it's just returning the login page - I had a typo.

text: If the authentication method is HTTP Basic Authentication, cookies are unnecessary. Usually cookies are generated when passwords are POSTed in a HTML form.

elements.text: If the authentication method is HTTP Basic Authentication, cookies are unnecessary. Usually cookies are generated when passwords are POSTed in a HTML form.

text: yeah, but they do like specifying the cookies flags in the docs...

elements.text: yeah, but they do like specifying the cookies flags in the docs...

text: (this is NASA)

elements.text: (this is NASA)

text: Using wget with the basic auth syntax doesn't work either by the way. But with `--user` or `--http-user` it works fine

elements.text: Using wget with the basic auth syntax doesn't work either by the way. But with
--user
or
--http-user
it works fine

text: Not sure what request wget is actually sending

elements.text: Not sure what request wget is actually sending

text: It takes 3 tries to get a 200, the first few are 302s/401s. HTTP.jl just returns the 302

elements.text: It takes 3 tries to get a 200, the first few are 302s/401s. HTTP.jl just returns the 302

text: compile wget with debug support and wget -d should get all the debug info. however, user:password@host should work the same as --user. If the password contains shell special characters, it should be quoted.

elements.text: compile wget with debug support and wget -d should get all the debug info. however, user:password@host should work the same as --user. If the password contains shell special characters, it should be quoted.

text: you can try `wget -S` to get server response headers.

elements.text: you can try
wget -S
to get server response headers.

text: thanks, arch seems to have debug on by default :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: thanks, arch seems to have debug on by default

text: I learned that because debug is disabled by homebrew :cry:

elements.text: I learned that because debug is disabled by homebrew

text: Arch is good for that kind of thing...

elements.text: Arch is good for that kind of thing...

text: It seems there is a redirect for oauth that wget is following but HTTP.jl isn't

elements.text: It seems there is a redirect for oauth that wget is following but HTTP.jl isn't

text: and wget also doesn't follow it if you use the `user:password@host` syntax

elements.text: and wget also doesn't follow it if you use the
user:password@host
syntax

text: That’s odd.

elements.text: That’s odd.

text: None of the keywords seem to make any difference

elements.text: None of the keywords seem to make any difference

text: I think the problem is that your server does not recognize HTTP.jl’s User-Agent string and thinks it’s a browser and returns a link to a login page. It will correctly recognize wget and curl and add  `app_type=401` in the redirect url. Add `["User-Agent" => "Wget/1.21.1"]` in your request should solve this.

elements.text: I think the problem is that your server does not recognize HTTP.jl’s User-Agent string and thinks it’s a browser and returns a link to a login page. It will correctly recognize wget and curl and add
app_type=401
in the redirect url. Add
["User-Agent" => "Wget/1.21.1"]
in your request should solve this.
